Quantum Paradigms for Optimization and Sampling
special_session_description:
Mathematical optimization and probabilistic sampling are indispensable components of modern decision-making, enabling people to rigorously model, analyze, and solve real-world problems in operations research, including logistics, finance, energy systems, and healthcare. Recently, quantum computing has gained attention in the OR community as a groundbreaking paradigm capable of solving complex computational problems faster than classical computers.

In this special session, we aim to narrow the gap between theorists and practitioners in quantum optimization and sampling.  The session consists of four talks:

Jiaqi Leng (Postdoctoral Researcher, UC Berkeley) and Lei Fan (Assistant Professor, University of Houston).  Quantum Hamiltonian Descent Algorithm for Nonlinear Optimization and Applications in Energy Systems
Guanyang Wang (Assistant Professor, Rutgers University).  A quantum-inside-quantum Monte Carlo algorithm
Ankit Kulshrestha (Senior Research Scientist, Fujitsu Research).  Looking in the future: Leveraging machine learning algorithms for quantum optimization
Mohammadhossein Mohammadisiahroudi (Postdoctoral Research Associate, Lehigh University).  On Accelerating Optimization Methods by Quantum Linear Algebra

session_name: Bridging the Gap between Academia and Industry
special_session_description:
This panel aims to foster a discussion towards a better understanding of

the current level of collaboration between academia and industry, highlighting the gap between where we are now and the potential for stronger collaboration, while acknowledging different expectations in both sectors,
the challenges faced by cross-disciplinary teams when solving real-world problems,
what can be done on both sides to close the gap in between.

special_session_description:
Join our panel discussion to find out more about professional licensing for ISE's. Professional licensure for Industrial and Systems Engineers provides several key benefits:

Recognition of Competence: Licensure demonstrates that an ISE has met specific educational and experience requirements, ensuring they possess the necessary knowledge and skills to practice in the field.
Protection if the Public: Licensure protects the public by ensuring that engineers adhere to ethical standards and professional conduct, thereby reducing the risk of incompetence or malpractice.
Marketability: Holding a professional license enhances an ISE's marketability and credibility to potential employers and clients, as it signifies a commitment to high standards and ongoing professional development.
Legal Standing: Licensure provides legal recognition of an ISE's expertise, enabling them to engage in certain activities that may require licensure, such as signing off on engineering designs or serving as expert witnesses in legal proceedings.
Global Mobility: In some cases, licensure can facilitate mobility across borders by allowing industrial engineers to practice internationally, provided they meet equivalent licensure requirements in other jurisdictions.
Overall, professional licensure enhances the reputation, credibility, and opportunities for ISE's while safeguarding the public interest. Join our panel discussion to hear how licensure could fit into your career path and then visit us at the NCEES booth for a free practice exam!

session_name: Women in Industrial & System Engineering:  How to be an advocate for women in the workplace
special_session_description: In today’s environment with Diversity, Equity and Inclusion being challenged and historical events are slowly being removed this becomes a challenging environment for women and minorities in the workplace. Come and join our panel discussion to understand how we can advocate and support our employees. This will be a great discussion not only for women but men to understand how we can help at all levels of leadership and understand the current or potential impacts.

session_name: Panel on ISE Careers in Consulting
special_session_description: Tens of thousands of ISEs chose to work in the consulting industry. Many begin their careers immediately after receiving an undergraduate or master’s degree. Others spending years working in another industry before transitioning to consulting. This session will be a panel discussion on the diverse careers ISEs can have working in the Consulting Industry. Panelists will describe how they got into consulting, their different experiences, some of their lessons learned and take questions from the audience.

session_name: Strategies for Finding a Work-Life Balance
special_session_description:
In today’s fast-paced and hyper-connected world, achieving a sustainable work-life balance has become a critical challenge for professionals. This panel session will explore actionable strategies and innovative approaches for balancing the demands of work and personal life.  ISE leaders of varied backgrounds will share their personal experiences describing what has and hasn’t worked for them.  

The session will also examine the role of leadership in modeling work-life balance and how organizational policies, such as hybrid work models and wellness programs, can support employees in achieving harmony between their professional and personal responsibilities.

This Special Session will consist of a panels of industry members spanning the most important career decisions engineers encounter, presented as a collaboration between the IAB and YP organizations. The first panel will include both early and late career professionals, with a focus on career planning and goal setting. Topics will include “How to prepare for your first job” and “How to transition from College to Career.” The second panel will focus on the process of successfully executing the first job change after graduating. Topics will include “How to know when the time is right” and “How to job hunt with industry experience”. Panelists will be young professionals who have recently completed their first job switch after graduating. The third panel will consist of Directors and VPs who will give advice on transitioning into upper management roles. Topics will include “Building visibility” and “Pros/Cons of additional degrees and certifications”.

session_name: Informing Cancer Control Policy Through Mathematical Modeling: The Cancer Intervention and Modeling Surveillance Modeling (CISNET) Experience
special_session_description: This presentation focuses on the pivotal role of mathematical modeling in optimizing breast cancer screening strategies, with a particular emphasis on the University of Wisconsin Breast Cancer Simulation Model (UWBCS), a member of the National Cancer Institute’s Cancer Intervention and Surveillance Modeling Network (CISNET). Research efforts in this area were initiated with the objective of developing personalized mammography screening schedules tailored to a woman’s individual risk profile and prior screening history. To this end, a finite-horizon partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) model was formulated and solved optimally. This presentation will provide an overview of the UWBCS model, including its development, key components, calibration processes, and real-world policy impacts, highlighting the profound influence that rigorous mathematical modeling can exert on public health decision-making.

Energy Systems Special Session: The PG&E Energy Analytics Challenge
special_session_description:
This special session will include technical presentations from the top-performing teams in the 2024-2025 PG&E Energy Analytics challenge, sponsored by Pacific Gas & Electric Company (PG&E), and co-organized by the IISE Energy Systems Division (ESD) and the INFORMS Quality, Statistics and Reliability (QSR) Section. The competition challenges individuals and teams to design an analytics-based solution to a practical energy systems’ challenge. This year’s challenge focused on forecasting electricity loads for a specific area within the CAISO system using multi-year historical load and exogenous weather information. The session will begin by an introduction of the challenge, given by a PG&E expert and the competition organizers, followed by technical talks by the top-performing teams.

session_name: Modeling and Simulation Workshop 1- Arena and FlexSim
special_session_description:
Title:Getting the most out of your Arena simulation model with data analytics tools
Abstract:Learn how to integrate your Arena simulation model with data analytics tools. Discover the built-in tools to integrate with Excel and other external data sources. See how to use data visualization tools to display results that go beyond the standard reports. Learn the basics of using the Arena object model to programmatically interact with your simulation model via Python opening the doors to using external Python libraries for machine learning, optimization, and more.
Presenter: Nathan Ivey, Arena, Rockwell Automation
 
Title:From Manual to Automated: Leveraging Autodesk FlexSim for Factory Simulation
Abstract: Design, improve, manage, and optimize operations through digital factory simulation using FlexSim from Autodesk. Using an example that compares manual and automated manufacturing approaches, this workshop demonstrates FlexSim’s powerful modeling and analysis capabilities including interoperability with AutoCAD and other Autodesk products, flexible automated pathfinding navigation, downtime management, versatile logic building, informative KPI dashboards, and much more. The workshop will also illustrate FlexSim’s diverse application domains beyond manufacturing and highlight some of the resources available to learn FlexSim.
Presenters: Trent Richards and Allen Greenwood, FlexSim, Autodesk

session_name: Modeling and Simulation Workshop 2 - Simio and AnyLogic
special_session_description:
itle: Using Simio's Data-Driven Data-Generated Approach to Develop, Maintain, and Operate Process Digital Twins
Abstract: This presentation explores Simio’s data-driven, data-generated approach to developing, maintaining, and applying process digital twins. While digital twins are widely used in manufacturing, they are equally valuable in other process-driven environments such as warehousing, healthcare operations, and service systems. We share technical insights and practical examples highlighting Simio’s modeling methodologies and tools for digital twin implementation. Key topics include custom objects, data integration through connectors, Simio Processes, and scripting support. Additionally, we introduce Simio University, a training platform that supports users in learning Simio modeling and development.
Presenter: Dr. Jeff Smith, Simio LLC
 
Title: Modern Methods, Languages, and Use Cases in Simulation Modeling
Abstract: A workshop from the vendor of AnyLogic – an agnostic multi-method simulation software with the largest worldwide user community. Based on AnyLogic usage statistics, we will show which modeling methods, techniques, and languages are most used today by the industry. This includes DES (process flowcharts), Agent-based modeling, Statecharts, System Dynamics, GIS-based modeling, and others. We will also talk about the recent (and very positive) shift from the project-based usage of simulation to operational use and, therefore, longer lifecycles of models (digital twinning, etc.); we will present some use cases and go through the new requirements to simulations. Finally, we will touch the current relationship of Simulation and AI: what worked, what did not work, and what to expect.

session_name: Approaches to Sustainable Energy and Resource Management (SDG 7)
The Industrial Engineer's Sustainability Role in the Changing Political Environment
special_session_description:
As an Industrial and Systems Engineer looking to help mitigate your company or community’s impact on Climate Change, how do you navigate the evolving landscape of sustainability, ESG, and DEI efforts, as the new U.S. federal administration challenges these initiatives while state governments and the European Union are increasingly mandating sustainability reporting. This session will explore a renewed focus on reducing energy, water, and material waste while lowering risk, placing industrial and systems engineers in pivotal roles driving sustainable practices. Engage with experts from the U.S., Europe, and Mexico to uncover strategies for resilience and innovation in this complex environment.

Vincent Hargaden, PhD, Head of School, University College Dublin, School of Mechanical & Materials Engineering,

Jesús Urzúa González, Director Programa de Ingeniería Industrial y de Sistemas, Escuela de Ingeniería y Ciencias, Tecnológico de Monterrey

Amin Esmaeili, PhD, PMP, Director of Georgia Industrial Assessment Center (Geo-IAC) and Co-Director of Southeastern Center of Excellence (SCoE), Kennesaw State University

Annual Volunteer Project Debrief and Recommendations
special_session_description: Join us for the Annual IISE Volunteer Project debriefing!  Meals on Wheels America is a nationwide organization with over 5,000 community-based programs serving 2.2 million seniors annually. Neighborhood Meals on Wheels in Sugar Hill, Georgia, serves over 200 seniors daily with freshly prepared lunches. There are two teams of ISEs volunteers: one to provide strategic consulting for their new 6,200-square-foot space and another to assist with food preparation and facility setup. They will share their experiences, recommendations, and insights on improving processes and enhancing the volunteer experience. Whether or not you participated in the project, your questions and suggestions are encouraged.

session_name: Global Sustainability Leadership: The Interplay of Policy, Education, and Technology
Revisiting the Sustainable Development Goals Two-thirds of the way to 2030
special_session_description: Revisit the Sustainable Development Goals –a shared blueprint for peace and prosperity, for people and the planet, now and into the future – ten years after their 2015 approval by almost all the worlds’ nations.  Do you know what the 17 Goals are and how they relate to each other, how things have changed since their approval, and what remains to be done? Most importantly what impact do they have on you personally and professionally as an Industrial and Systems Engineer?  Join us for an interactive workshop providing context for your career and the IISE Sustainable Development Track.

session_name: Decision Analytics for Service and Supply Chain Optimization

special_session_description:
This session's presentations are formatted as a workshop. 

Emerging Trends: The Role of AI in Continuous Improvement

Authors: Elizabeth Cudney, Raja Jayaraman, and Sandra Furterer

Abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) continues to evolve, its impact on continuous improvement initiatives is becoming increasingly significant. This session explores emerging trends in AI applications within Lean, Six Sigma, and other process optimization methodologies. We will discuss how AI-driven tools enhance data-driven decision-making, automate root cause analysis, and improve predictive capabilities for quality and efficiency improvements. Case studies and real-world examples will highlight how organizations are integrating AI into their continuous improvement efforts to drive innovation, reduce waste, and enhance operational performance.

 

AI as Your Fifth Team Member

Authors: Chad Laux, John Springer, and Seyi Ogunmodede

Abstract: Over the past 18 months, the advances in artificial intelligence have been unprecedented.  How this new technology may be incorporated is of great importance and concern. What are AI capabilities that the practitioner may take advantage of? What are some of the ethical considerations of AI adoption and usage? In this talk, how AI may assist you as an asset, will be discussed. Specific topics include a brief history of AI, AI tool sets, AI ethical concerns, and AI tasking in Lean.

 

AI-Enabled Value Stream Mapping: Leveraging AI for Process Optimization

Authors: Elizabeth Cudney and Adil Dalal

Abstract: Value stream mapping (VSM) is a critical tool for identifying inefficiencies and driving process improvements. In this interactive workshop, participants will explore how AI can enhance VSM by generating insights that identify bottlenecks and optimize future-state processes. Using a hands-on approach, attendees will work with a current state value stream map and learn how to develop AI-powered prompts to analyze constraints, suggest improvement opportunities, and support data-driven decision-making. This session will provide a framework for integrating AI into VSM to improve process efficiency, reduce waste, and create more agile operations.
Participants will:

session_name: Data-Driven Systems for Quality and Operational Excellence
Panel: Community Organizations and Human-Centered Design: Challenges and Opportunities at the Intersection
special_session_description: This panel aims to discuss the challenges and opportunities at the intersection of community organizations and human-centered design. Community organizations play a crucial role in addressing local needs and implementing interventions that involve the design and delivery of products, processes, policies, places, and pedagogy (5Ps), but they face significant challenges in identifying resources and translating needs and evidence into design solutions. Human factors engineering (HFE) can contribute to addressing these challenges through structured frameworks, tools, and methods for human-centered design. However, HFE researchers and practitioners might lack know-how about best practices to engage in the community and address these challenges. This panel aims to bring together HFE experts in design, user experience, and entrepreneurial thinking; accessibility experts with industry experience; a community outreach expert; and partners from community organizations to discuss key challenges and needs of community partners in the design and delivery of 5Ps, and how HFE researchers and industry experts can address these challenges.

session_name: M&D Best Student Paper Award Finalists
Track Keynote Session on Future Manufacturing
special_session_description: The technological foundations of advanced manufacturing continue to rapidly evolve as ubiquitous sensing, cloud computing and storage, and next generation controllers are introduced into the manufacturing ecosystem. This talk presents some of the technical concepts and business models that will enable new technologies and capabilities in the manufacturing sector to be rapidly deployed throughout the U.S. industrial base. Insight will be presented into next generation resilient production operations and business models that favor local and point of assembly manufacturing. Democratization of manufacturing efforts will be highlighted as an exemplar of efforts at the Advanced Manufacturing Pilot Facility at Georgia Tech by focusing on the integration of real-time sensor data via edge/fog/cloud operations as applied to state-of-the-art hot wire laser hybrid (additive and subtractive) manufacturing processes. Both design and manufacturing issues will be addressed as they relate to improved control of next generation production systems. The hybrid system is an ideal platform for digital integration as it combines newer metal additive processes with much more classical machining capabilities. The talk will conclude with a discussion of how rapidly advancing technical innovations will be propagated throughout the manufacturing enterprise, ensuring a state-of-the-art manufacturing economy. This will provide opportunities for businesses of all sizes and democratize advanced manufacturing technologies throughout the United States.

As the U.S. manufacturing sector faces increasing global competition, workforce transitions, and rapid technological change, cross-sector collaboration has never been more critical. This panel will explore how national manufacturing institutes, industrial partners, and government agencies are working together to accelerate innovation, strengthen domestic supply chains, and translate cutting-edge research into real-world manufacturing solutions. Panelists will share insights on public-private partnership models, technology transition pathways, and strategies to scale innovation from pilot to production. Attendees will gain perspectives on emerging priorities in areas such as digital transformation, cybersecurity, energy resilience, and workforce upskilling — and how these efforts are being coordinated across organizational boundaries.

session_name: Manufacturing & Design Track Town Hall Meeting
special_session_description: Work in small groups to integrate EM elements into a course or training session of their choice, whether in academia or industry

session_name: Achieving Zero Incidents: The World Class Manufacturing Safety Approach
special_session_description: The World Class Manufacturing (WCM) methodology has been widely adopted across industries to drive cost savings and efficiency improvements. While WCM is well known for its impact on operational excellence, its role in occupational health and safety is often overlooked. The WCM safety pillar embraces a ZERO mindset, meaning the ultimate goal is zero safety incidents. It provides a structured, step-by-step methodology to systematically eliminate workplace hazards. A key strength of the WCM approach lies in its rigorous root cause analysis and proactive risk assessment. It integrates hazard identification with compliance standards and extends risk assessment beyond unsafe conditions to include human errors and unsafe behaviors, forming a comprehensive risk prediction model. Additionally, WCM emphasizes horizontal deployment, ensuring that preventive measures are expanded across all operations. Beyond technical measures, WCM fosters a strong safety culture through management audits, operator-led safety committees, and structured engagement at all levels of the organization. By linking safety improvements to human behavior and error mechanisms, WCM provides a holistic framework for sustainable workplace safety. This tutorial will explore the WCM safety pillar’s methodology, tools, and real-world applications within the Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG) industry, offering practical insights into this structured and effective approach to safety management.

session_name: M&D Best Track Papar Award Finalists
Cybersecurity Education for Engineers: Action for Cyber Resiliency
special_session_description: Join our dynamic panel of academic and industry leaders for an essential conversation on embedding cyber-physical resilience into the design and operation of critical industrial environments, such as manufacturing and energy sectors. Industry experts will illuminate key lessons from major industrial cybersecurity incidents while academic thought leaders share cutting-edge research, educational insights, and impactful industry-academia collaborations. Our panelists are dedicated to empowering a new generation of engineers skilled in frontier technologies—including cybersecurity and AI—to secure increasingly complex cyber-physical systems.

session_name: Special Session 1 - Expert Panel – Supply Chain Resilience
special_session_description: This expert panel on Supply Chain Resilience will critically re-examine traditional strategies in light of challenges and gaps revealed during and after COVID-19, focusing on how rapid changes in global trading policies and the adoption of advanced technologies like IoT and AI are transforming supply chain management. Panelists will discuss the current state and future direction of resilience, highlighting the shift toward digitalization, real-time visibility, and data-driven decision-making to enhance agility and adaptability in an era of ongoing disruption.

session_name: Data Science for Industrial Excellence: From Statistical Process Control to Deep Learning
special_session_description: Modern, data-rich industrial environments present both a challenge and an opportunity. Uncovering key insights from a deluge of data is rarely straightforward, but doing it well unlocks a level of industrial excellence that is unattainable otherwise. In this presentation, a JMP® technical staff member will review lessons learned from real JMP customers about achieving industrial excellence through data science methods, from advanced statistical process control to machine learning methods for data mining and predictive modeling. Examples will be accompanied by brief demonstrations of techniques implemented in JMP statistical software.

session_name: AI and Analytics for Human-Centered Systems
Engineering People and Team Performance Excellence
special_session_description:
Join us for an engaging session introducing IISE's new Engineering People and Team Performance Community. Discover executive insights into our upcoming professional development sessions from January to May, culminating in our conference.

Explore an innovative AI-enabled application designed to enhance Personal and Professional Mastery and foster Social Fitness. Gain insights into the Foundational Principles that underpin personal and professional growth, and learn strategies for integrating engineering principles into traditionally softer sciences through strategic HR partnerships. Discover how these collaborations can significantly impact Organizational Excellence and Enterprise Value.

This session will be interactive, featuring small group exercises to facilitate learning and networking opportunities.

room_name: Grand Ballroom I | Renaissance Waverly Hotel
special_session_description: This session provides detailed instructions on the engineering management competition.  No experience is assumed on the part of the participants.  The orientation and training covers all aspects of the *game*, the competition scoring, and the rewards involved.  There is no entry fee, but the competition is limited to no more than 10 student teams and no more than 10 practitioner teams.  There are two prize categories:  student and practitioner.  The game is being sponsored by FlexSim-Autodesk.  Snacks and drinks will be provided (sponsored by TAMU).   The student chapter at Ohio State University will assist in the conduct of the game.

room_name: Grand Ballroom I | Renaissance Waverly Hotel
special_session_description:
The management decision making game has decision makers make production resource decisions for a small manufacturing operation.  The number and types of decisions are aligned to the kind that would be made for an actual operation.  Scoring is focused on performance, revenues, and costs incurred from the decisions made.  The model is run for an equal time horizon for all participants to ensure a common basis of comparison.  The game takes roughly 45-50 minutes to play.  Winners (1st, 2nd, and 3rd) will be identified at the end of the session.  Prize sponsors:  Solomon Bruce Consulting, Texas A&M University

Note:

The competition is open to all. There is no entry fee for the competition. Food and beverages will be provided. 
Please ensure you bring your PC, capable of running the Windows operating system, to be able to participate in the competition.

session_name: Modern Methods, Languages, and Use Cases in Simulation Modeling
special_session_description: A workshop from the vendor of AnyLogic – an agnostic multi-method simulation software with the largest worldwide user community. Based on AnyLogic usage statistics, we will show which modeling methods, techniques, and languages are most used today by the industry. This includes DES (process flowcharts), Agent-based modeling, Statecharts, System Dynamics, GIS-based modeling, and others. We will also talk about the recent (and very positive) shift from the project-based usage of simulation to operational use and, therefore, longer lifecycles of models (digital twinning, etc.); we will present some use cases and go through the new requirements to simulations. Finally, we will touch the current relationship of Simulation and AI: what worked, what did not work, and what to expect.
